speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll now hear argument in Lincoln Property v. Roche. Mr. Frederick.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, I thought (b) simply enacted a special necessary condition when you had a local defendant.  I thought it was not an eligibility provision.  I thought it was a  limitation provision.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, it's consistent with it, but I -- it seems to me that it's a bit of a stretch to say that anyone who is properly joined and served, at least in a formal sense, is, therefore, the only person who may be considered in a -- in a diversity inquiry.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So, I take it your answer to Justice Souter is yes.  In other words, if the mistake that the court made was relying on 1441(b), it was a similar mistake for you, in your opening brief, to put such weight on that language in 1441(b).

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Frederick, what about cases where a plaintiff sues two defendants -- one is diverse, and the other is not diverse -- and there is a motion by the defendants to dismiss for want of diversity?  The plaintiff then says, "Oh, but only one of those defendants is the 'real-party whatever,' and I can drop the other one, because the other one is not the 'real party in interest'"? Now, that's a situation where courts, even if this court has never had that problem, have said, "If the  second defendant, the non-diverse defendant, is a 'real party,' you can't get rid of the case that way, but if it's not -- if it's not, you can keep the -- just drop it and keep the case going against the 'real party in interest.'"  There are such cases.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Ah, but the plaintiff said, "This is a complicated real estate business, and I want to discover whether there is -- whether the 'true defendant' is a Virginia citizen, as I am."  So, on the face of it, it looks like there's  complete diversity, but, in fact, the diverse defendant is hiding the "real party."  I think that's the position that the plaintiff was taking.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The plaintiff --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- the plaintiff points to two offices of the defendant, who's -- the defendant is described by defendant as a Texas corporation -- but there was one witness -- Chaney, was it? -- who said that Lincoln is not a corporation.  It is a partnership.  No corporate board.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, they thought they got closer with a witness named Franzen, who was a Virginia resident, and who also described Lincoln as a partnership, and himself as a partner.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Frederick, earlier you made the point that Lincoln was a proper "real party in interest."  I take it that's not critical to your position.  Your argument would be the same if they weren't a real party in interest, wouldn't it?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But if they -- if they don't have a proper defendant, they should do that?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I presume, then --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- that the plaintiff loses, not that you get to have the court find the proper defendant for the plaintiff.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Frederick --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- will you just clarify one thing for me?  Did the defendant ever take the position in this litigation, in discovery or anywhere along the line, that they sued their own defendant?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, plaintiff certainly wouldn't want to say there's an indispensable party missing, I take it, because then that would put the plaintiff out of court.  The plaintiff is arguing that there's another defendant who should be in here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And because you represent the removing defendant, it is true, is it not, that the removing defendant has the burden of showing that proper diversity exists?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What -- I know you  contend that's not the case, but let's say there is a in-State subsidiary that's completely responsible for all the challenged actions, and the in-State plaintiff sues an -- only the out-of-State parent. What happens in that case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Frederick, would you clarify one thing for me?  I don't know how we even get to the second question, about partnership. If you're right that Lincoln is a corporation -- it's a Texas corporation, with its principal place of business in Texas, end of case; it's the only named defendant -- so, how do we get to something about a partnership?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, I don't understand it.  We wouldn't vacate the judgment in part.  If we reversed, --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- that's the end of  it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes, but, Mr. Frederick, before that -- you know, read back -- the court -- the Fourth Circuit has said, "It appears that the real and substantial party in interest is this Virginia subsidiary, be it a partnership, be it a corporation." So, it's -- the thing about nexus is not self-standing.  The court is positing that there is a Virginia corporation or a Virginia partnership in  the picture, and then says, "And given that, not only is it -- is it a Virginia entity, but it's got this close nexus because of -- it's operating substantially there, as well."

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Am I correct, though, this entity we're talking about is not a party to the case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Frederick. Mr. Joseph.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Was what?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Then why did you name it, in the complaint, as the defendant?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Then you'll be left without  -- if you've named the wrong defendant, then you have a suit against no defendant.  It seems to me you are automatically dismissed.  You didn't substitute another defendant.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I've never heard of that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I thought, if you sue A, and then it turns out A doesn't own the building, well, then you've got to sue B.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And you didn't sue B.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, that's too bad, that, unfortunately, if you don't know who owns the building, it's going to be hard for you to bring the lawsuit.  But we had, I thought, like, pages and pages of discovery rules and -- I've never heard, before, of a lawyer who has a -- you know, in this kind of situation, can't find out who owns a building there.  There are records, there are all kinds of things.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I've looked through the appendix, actually.  I read the joint appendix, insofar as the opinion cited it.  And it cited, in the opinion, several -- five factors -- and I guess there are no others, though you can bring them out if there were -- that supported you.  And the only two that seemed to say that it had something to do - - that seemed to have anything at all to do with suggesting that there was no diversity -- was Mr. Fred Chaney, which said that it was a partnership and not a company.  I read that.  That didn't seem to me to be what he said.  And then somebody called Mr. LeBeau, who said that Franzen is a senior vice president and -- a Virginia resident -- and partner in Lincoln Property.  So, I looked up that, and it was on, like, page 273 and, I think, 173 there.  And they asked Mr. LeBeau, and he says, "Lincoln operates through many different structures, and I  don't know what they were using here."  Am I right - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- or did I misread it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.  So --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- what is the evidence?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Where is it in the appendix?  It said that he -- you sue person X, and I take it the reason that you won this case in the Fourth Circuit -- which was surprising to me -- was that a person called Mr. Franzen, who is a resident of Virginia, was a partner of the defendant.  Now, I  would like -- and, indeed, it was a partnership of which he was a partner.  So, if a Virginia resident is a partner of the defendant, which is a partnership, then maybe you were right. So, I'm interested in: What is the evidence that Mr. Franzen was a partner of the defendant, which is a partnership?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What page --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- is that?  Is that a --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, that's better than what is in the opinion.  What is it?  181.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And how about joint appendix 239 and 275, both of which say that Franzen was not a partner in any entity responsible for managing the apartments in question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, Mr. Joseph, I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- I thought we had to decide whether an unnamed private party should be considered for jurisdictional purposes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: And do you have any case supporting that proposition?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But the -- it sounds to me -- if I understood your answer correctly, you're talking about cases in which the named party citizenship is disregarded.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Where the question is, Should an unnamed party citizenship "be" regarded?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Then there's no defendant.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yeah, but he didn't come  in to defend; you pulled him in to defend.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And the problem that I have with your position is, I don't know of anything in the record that indicates that he wasn't ready to defend, that he wouldn't have -- or it wasn't ready to defend, that it wouldn't have paid the judgment, that you could have -- could not have gotten, from the party you named, all the relief that you were asking for.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay.  But so far as the Fourth Circuit -- tell me if I'm wrong here -- it sounds to me that the Fourth Circuit took the following position, that for purposes of determining diversity, it is not enough to name a principal who may be liable for the acts of subsidiaries, without naming the subsidiary, or, if you name a -- I'm mixing up principal and corporation --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- principal and --  corporate parent and subsidiary, or principal and business agent.  And I don't know of any rule to the effect that, for diversity purposes, a plaintiff simply cannot choose to sue the parent, or to sue the principal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay.  Where would I be wrong?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But you named Lincoln as the defendant.  And I'm looking at your second amended complaint, which says, "Lincoln," on information and belief, "is a corporation with its  headquarters in Dallas, and it is the developer and manager of the property."  That's what you alleged in your complaint.  You allege that Lincoln was the manager -- Lincoln, whose Texas corporation was the manager of the property in question.  Now, would you -- you're saying that that was wrong, and you should have sued somebody else, and the Court should cure that for you?  That's -- it's really bizarre.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He's a real party if you sued him.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Just because you're going to lose doesn't mean that he's not a real party.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It seems to me anybody you sue is a real party.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But they -- let me stop you on that "real party," because, as has been pointed out, the "real party in interest" concept, as a procedural matter, comes out of rule 17, and it's talking about plaintiffs, that suits have to be brought in the name of the real party so that the defendant isn't in a situation where he's sued one day by plaintiff A, and is not home free when plaintiff B comes in with the identical complaint. So, it was originally designed with, Who is the proper party, the assignee or the assignor?  That's what real party -- that's what the concept is familiarly about.  Who is the proper plaintiff, not defendant?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Rule 17 is about joinder of parties; it's not about jurisdiction.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So, that's -- it's something different.  It's a -- it's a whole other animal, because "real party in interest," as used in the Federal rules, is a device -- is a joinder device, is in the joinder rules.  Now you're saying, "Ah, but there's some other real-party concept out there that has to do with jurisdiction."

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought Carden was about: In a partnership, does every partner's  citizenship count?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There wasn't any question that -- that it was the right or the -- that the defendant was a wrong defendant or that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But to get the real parties before the court, you have to sue them.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And, apparently, you didn't sue the right people until you replied to me. Then I took your argument, because it seemed like seven arguments, mixed up, and I took that argument to be the following.  I'm -- I, the plaintiff, sued a defendant, who is called the Lincoln Property Company.  Now, I grant you, there is some evidence that that defendant, the one I sued, is a Texas corporation.  One, they showed us the certificate of incorporation, or they got a sworn statement.  Two,  in my complaint, I said that's what he was. However, there is some evidence the other way.  On page 179 and 181, we have a person named Mr. Franzen who says, "I am the senior president, vice president, partner for defendant Lincoln Property Company," in which case, if that's your argument, you're telling us -- is that your argument, that there is some evidence the real defendant, whom I sued, is not a corporation, despite the apparent evidence to the contrary?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Rather, it is a partner, and Mr. Franzen is a partner in it.  Is that your argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Do you want to make that argument here, or are you going to give up on that argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, if they said they were, then it seems to me -- why don't you just hold them to it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, it seems very odd that they -- they say, "We were," and you say, "Oh, no, you weren't."  [Laughter.]

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: "We shouldn't have sued you."  Why don't you just take them at their word and sue them?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: But it isn't up to the court of appeals to make some kind of roving inquiry of who would have been a better defendant.  It just seems to me the Fourth Circuit rule is totally unworkable and unprecedented.  I don't see how you can possibly overcome that, because the plaintiff is the master of its complaint, and it can decide who to sue.  And Lincoln was sued as a corporation, and I don't see what business it is of a court to say, "Oh, it should have been somebody else."

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, you can move, as a party to the case, to dismiss somebody who's sued for some reason, but that isn't what happened here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, what if they did? Suppose they did say, "Not me," and you proceeded with your lawsuit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay?  What would happen?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: They would win the judgment.  Would they be the real party in that controversy?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Of course they would be. Because you sued them.  Even if they're innocent -- are you saying all innocent parties are not parties to the controversy?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't think so.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But we don't know --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- who that party is. Let's go back to your -- when you started this case, you said that you would, on discovery -- this is what you said in -- at the time of your initial complaint -- determine if there is an additional defendant, or defendants, who should be  named as parties.  What discovery did you pursue to find out if there was an additional defendant, or defendants, who should be named as parties?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Has any knowledge of --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- the what of --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Oh.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Joseph, can I ask you to go back to the beginning for a second?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: They filed a reply brief.  There are a lot of disputes about the facts. Do you concede that the Lincoln Property Company that you sued is a Texas corporation?  --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Do you acknowledge that the corporation that you sued, Lincoln Property Company, is a Texas corporation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I understood them to be arguing, in essence, that there's some other entity that really is the real party in interest.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But you dispute, as a matter of fact, that Lincoln Property Company is a Texas corporation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I'm asking you a --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- very simple "yes" or "no" question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Is this corporation a Texas corporation?  The one you sued.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So, you say yes, it is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, I'd like the -- these are very expensive, this litigation.  You're all the way in the Supreme Court.  It's costing people a lot of money.  And if there is a legal issue here, I'd like to find out what it is. I have exactly the same question Justice Stevens had, which is where I started.  Do you agree that the company you sued, called Lincoln Property, is a Texas corporation, yes or no?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Then that's out -- fine, that's out of the case.  The next question is -- of course you could sue a real company, called Lincoln Property or Jolly Fisherman, and it could turn out that that real company is a front, that it has no real existence, its -- all its papers and everything to do with it is signed by a totally separate corporation.  Are you saying that's what happened here?  And if that's what happened here, which is the real corporation and people in interest?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm not talking about burden-of-proof failure.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm asking you, Who is the real corporation or person in interest that Lincoln Property is a kind of sham or front for?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.  Then you think --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm getting there.  I'm not arguing with you.  I'm getting there.  Then you think that whoever it is that they are the front for has -- is a Virginia resident.  Is that what you think?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Might be a Virginia resident.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Might be.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You think there is a real party there that might be a Virginia resident.  And do you have any idea whatsoever of what that real party is called?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And what's the evidence that there is a Virginia resident, in there?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But the failure of the burden of proof is apparently a function of the Fourth Circuit's assumption that if you sue the parent, you have a duty to negate the possibility of suing any subsidiary; or if you sue the principal, you have an obligation to negate the possibility of suing any agent.  And I don't see where that comes, except out of the sky somewhere.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So, everything turned on the nominal-party finding.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: On the nominal-party assumption.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But if the Fourth Circuit is wrong on nominal party, that's the end of the case for your side.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, but the burden-of- proof issue, as you've just answered my question, does not arise until the Fourth Circuit finds that Lincoln is a nominal party.  And if, in fact, that conclusion is incorrect, then there's no burden-of- proof issue that has -- or no burden of proof that has not been satisfied.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Joseph, do I take it that the essence of your position is that a removing defendant, if that removing party is a corporation, must disclose all affiliates that may have been involved in the -- in the occurrence that the plaintiff might have, but failed, to name as a defendant, that a defendant -- although, on the surface, there's complete diversity, a defendant corporation must, in order to remove, identify all subsidiaries and affiliates who might have been sued, as well?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But defendant never took the position, "Not me."

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Defendant said --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- "Yes, we are the responsible party."

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes, but I also --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- pointed out it's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- this question?  Did you engage in discovery trying to determine who the real party in interest was?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, did he -- did he do a thorough job of trying to find out who the real party in interest --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Wouldn't it be his  burden, if he thought it was the wrong person?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yeah, but if you accept the representation, then they sued the right people.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: It would seem to me --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- if there was a dispute about this, it ought to -- there ought to have been extensive discovery before you got to the court of appeals.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, you had no - - I mean, you had no real reason to do it.  You had somebody there who accepted responsibility, in the  sense that they were willing to defend on the merits, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And it's only because you lost that you now question whether or not they should have accepted -- you're saying they shouldn't have accepted responsibility, and shouldn't have defended on the merits.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Joseph.  Mr. Frederick, you have nine minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But I guess what he's saying -- I'm trying to put the -- as good a light on it as I can -- it's a -- that if, in fact -- if a  big real-estate developer, which is a corporation -- what they do is, they organize a lot of deals, and their deals would take the form of hundreds and hundreds of limited partnerships, which are owned buildings in various States.  And I think he's saying, "Well, for diversity purposes, we should consider the citizenship of the parent corporation to be the citizenship of the limited partnership that happens to have control of the building that we're complaining about."

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, he thinks --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- you are responsible, but he thinks you ought to have the citizenship of  the intermediate entities that own, or manage directly, the building.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr.  Frederick. The case is submitted. [Whereupon, at 11:57 a.m., the case in the above-entitled matter was submitted.]
